Atrimonas thermophila is a strictly anaerobic (requiring no oxygen) and chemoheterotrophic (obtaining energy and carbon from organic compounds) archaeon. It is capable of growing at temperatures ranging from 50°C to 80°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 70°C.

Morphologically, Atrimonas thermophila cells are irregular coccoid (spherical) in shape, approximately 1-2 micrometers in diameter. The cells lack a cell wall but possess a cell membrane that is adapted to withstand the high temperatures of its natural habitat.

Genetically, Atrimonas thermophila has a circular chromosome and its genome has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and adaptations to the extreme thermal environment. It is capable of utilizing a variety of organic compounds, such as carbohydrates and amino acids, as energy and carbon sources.

This thermophilic archaeon is of scientific interest due to its unique adaptations to thrive in high-temperature ecosystems and its potential applications in biotechnology, such as the production of thermostable enzymes or the study of microbial diversity in extreme environments.
